metadata.h1: Data Science Certificate, Bootcamp, or Master’s Degree: Which is Best for Your Career?

all_paragraphs: Whether you’ve studied for years or are just now considering the transition, you’ll need to have the right toolset if you expect to succeed in the data science field. Rigorous and competitive, the field demands applicants stay up to speed on the latest info and data science practices.

In this guide, I’ll go over three different certification methods that can help you make a career in data science: data science certificates, data science bootcamps, and a data science master’s degree. Specifically, I’ll go over the pros and cons of each to give you a better idea of which is right for you.

A data science certificate is a professional certificate that teaches foundational data science skills. These certificates are offered by a number of universities and institutions and can theoretically aid in job recruitment across a variety of data-related IT fields (but more on that later).
There are a number of pros to obtaining a data science certificate:

You can’t expect to get any job in data science without a proper portfolio. A data science certificate can help you build just that. Though the certificate will provide only foundational knowledge, it will still help you lay the groundwork for a quality portfolio later on.

Compared to data science bootcamps and master’s degrees, which can run in the several thousands of dollars, data science certificates can be obtained for prices even under $500. This is great for those wishing to build their skillset and portfolios at a low cost.

Some certificates can be finished in a matter of weeks (and on your own schedule). Due to the low level of rigor, individuals can expect to complete these certificates quickly and without needing to abdicate prior commitments (including work, studies, and child-rearing).
Before making a decision, be sure to consider the cons of data science certificates, as well:

Data science certificates, while useful for those just getting into the field, aren’t the right choice for those seeking more advanced IT jobs, as the information provided in these certificates is generally only foundational.
· Does Not Directly Aid in Employment

Because of this, data science certificates do not directly aid in employment, by which I mean that no employer will hire you based off a certificate alone. Instead, you’ll need extensive work experience and/or more professional experience (including master’s or PhD training in ancillary fields).

Data science bootcamps offer a more rigorous and potentially beneficial way to advance in the IT world of data science. These bootcamps, designed to provide more in-depth and advanced knowledge, provide more useful information and generally look better on resumes — though they may not benefit complete beginners and could vary wildly in quality across program.
There are several pros to enrolling in a data science bootcamp:

As the name implies, data science bootcamps are famous for their academic rigor and intensity. Typically, these programs span a period of three or so months and seek to provide as much knowledge as possible within that limited time frame. While the breadth of knowledge doesn’t reach that of a data science master’s degree, these bootcamps offer a deeper dive than most certificate programs.

Perhaps an even bigger benefit of data science bootcamps is their focus on job preparation. Remember that these programs benefit from sending as many graduates as possible into the work force. For this reason, you can expect instructors to work with you closely on building a resume or CV that’s attractive to employers. This includes giving you the opportunity to work on projects that are beneficial to your career advancement.

Data science bootcamps can also connect you to major players in your field and are thus a good way to get your name out there. Depending on the reputability of your bootcamp (remember, not all are created equal), you will have a chance to see and interact with employers in the data science field and be able to prepare a resume that catches their eye.
Data science bootcamps are not without their drawbacks, however:

Don’t expect to continue with a normal life while studying at a data science bootcamp. These time-consuming programs practically demand your full focus, making it hard to work (in some cases, even part time) or concentrate on other studies while enrolled.

Another downside is the cost to these bootcamps, which can range anywhere from $5,000-$20,000. That’s some serious cash, especially if you’re not even sure you want to enter the field. Compounding this is the fact that these bootcamps are generally best undergone by individuals who already have PhD-level knowledge in ancillary math and science fields and thereby may be able to get a job even without them.

Individuals may also consider enrolling in a data science master’s degree program. Without a doubt the most professional of the three options, these programs are also the costliest and take the longest to obtain. Still, in the demanding world of data science, there’s little that’s coveted more than a graduate degree.
You can expect a number of pros from a data science master’s degree, including:

You know the first thing employers in the field are going to notice about your CV? That’s right — whether you have an advanced degree in the subject. There’s no way around it: having a graduate degree in data science will skyrocket your employment chances.

Master’s degree programs also provide excellent networking opportunities, as you can interact with professionals in the field while building a portfolio that will help in the real world. While you may not receive the same job prep that you would from a bootcamp, you can still expect a reasonable amount of game-changing networking before entering the field.

Of course, graduate degree programs offer you incredible internship opportunities that greatly benefit your career chances. Internships are one of the primary ways to gain real experience in the field and build a portfolio employers care about. Therefore, individuals should strongly consider enrolling in a grad program if they have the time and resources.
Still, there are some cons that you should consider before making that leap:

You don’t need me to tell you there’s a high cost involved in completing a master’s program. Depending on your region and school, you could be talking costs that range in the tens of thousands. This, coupled with high demand in the field, means you would be spending large amounts of money without any guarantee of being immediately hired.

Additionally, data science master’s degrees could take up to three-and-a-half years to obtain, meaning you won’t be able to enter the workforce any time soon. That doesn’t mean you should bite the bullet and go for a cheaper option if you’re lacking experience, however.

Finding the right data science program takes time and consideration. In general, data science master’s degrees offer the best chance at real success, though they may not be necessary depending on your prior qualifications. If you’ve already obtained an advanced degree in related fields such as analytics, math, science, or computer science, you may benefit the most from a data science bootcamp. If you’re simply testing the waters and considering a career transition, data science certificates are the best bet for you.
